content: Were these trucks worth a darn, looks aside? Always see them going real cheap and wasn't sure if it purely a cosmetic looks thing or if there was more...
author: CuriousBuyer

content: I used to drive a 379EXHD with a 475 cummins and a 13spd and I averaged 6.8 to 7.5mpg loaded to the knats ass with pork bellies.
author: Ironturkey

content: Most trucking companies, regardless of make and model of truck, tend to spec the trucks with engines between 435 and 475 hp. A lot of this has to do with fuel economy. As mentioned before, when a truck is ordered, it can be done so with practically any HP engine you want as well as rear end and tranny combo that will work with that engine.
author: Uturn2001

content: Because it's like driving a building through the wind, no aerodynamics to it. You can spec. any make, model truck with any engine you want, depends what your needs are. These days with the price of fuel, aerodynamics and fuel economy are more important to companies and most O/OPs. The most expensive cost in trucking is fuel. Alot of Pete owners put unmuffled straight exhaust pipes on the trucks, hence the loudness.
author: boneebone

content: There's something I've been wondering about Peterbilt trucks. It seems like all the trucks with the more powerful engines (over 500 hp) are box model trucks and not the round model. Why is it that when I'm going down the road, the box model peterbilts are louder than hell?
author: Douglas

content: I don't know too much, but here's what my experience has shown me. To me, they (Peterbilts) are way overrated. We have a few in our fleet, along with a few Freightliner Classics, and now a couple Western Star 4900ex's. Doing mostly local work, climbing in and out of the truck multiple times a day, the Freightliners have held up really well, and are really driver friendly. Same goes for the Western Stars. The Peterbilts, which are 379's, have been the most troublesome. They all are 2000 or 2001 models.
author: FleetOperator

content: 2004 379 Pete. Can't get fuel to the engine. Replaced lift pump, checked lines, still nothing. Anyone dealt with this before?
author: drummroya768

content: Service brake wail sound on my 579. Happens when I first apply brakes in the morning. Goes away after a few stops. Normal wear or something to worry about?
author: Rockhound11

content: Service brake pedal almost goes to the floor on my 389. Had the brakes checked and they say pads are fine. What else could cause this?
author: Hulld

content: 2015 Peterbilt 389 fuel pump replacement cost me $2800 at the dealer. Is that reasonable or did I get ripped off?
author: Jennyspete

content: Just bought my first Peterbilt - a 2020 579 with 200k miles. Previous owner took great care of it. Any tips for a first-time Pete owner?
author: NewPeteOwner

content: The 389 is hands down the best looking truck on the road. I've owned Kenworths, Freightliners, and Internationals. Nothing compares to the presence of a well-maintained 389.
author: TruckCollector

content: Thinking about ordering a new 579 with the EPIQ package. Anyone have real-world fuel economy numbers? The dealer claims 9+ mpg but I'm skeptical.
author: FuelConscious

content: My 2019 579 has been in the shop 6 times in 2 years for electrical issues. Wiring harness problems, sensor failures, you name it. Love the truck otherwise but this is getting old.
author: ElectricalNightmare

content: Best aftermarket upgrades for the 389? Looking to improve comfort on long hauls. Already have a good mattress, thinking about suspension seats and better lighting.
author: ComfortSeeker

content: Peterbilt dealer quoted me $45,000 for a reman Paccar MX-13. Is it worth it or should I just trade the truck in? It's a 2017 579 with 650k miles.
author: EngineDecision

content: Running a small fleet of 5 Peterbilt 579s. Overall happy with them but parts availability has been an issue lately. Anyone else experiencing long wait times for common parts?
author: SmallFleetOwner

content: The Cummins X15 in my 389 is bulletproof. 800k miles and still going strong. Just regular maintenance - oil changes, filters, and the occasional injector. Best engine I've ever had.
author: CumminsLoyalist

content: Comparing insurance rates between my old Freightliner and new Peterbilt. The Pete costs about 15% more to insure. Is this normal? Same driving record, same routes.
author: InsuranceQuestion

content: Just finished a cross-country run in my 579 UltraLoft. The sleeper is amazing - actually got good rest at truck stops. Worth every penny of the upgrade.
author: LongHaulComfort

content: Warning to anyone buying used Peterbilts: check the frame for cracks around the fifth wheel area. Seen too many trucks with hidden damage that sellers don't disclose.
author: UsedTruckWarning

content: The 567 is the perfect mixer truck. We run 8 of them and they handle the weight and tight job sites better than anything else we've tried. Highly recommend for vocational work.
author: ConcreteBoss

content: Peterbilt's financing options are terrible compared to Freightliner. Higher rates, less flexibility. Had to go through a third party to get a decent deal on my 389.
author: FinancingFrustration

content: Love my 389 but the turning radius is awful for city work. Should have gotten a 579 for the routes I'm running. Live and learn I guess.
author: CityDriverRegret

content: Peterbilt customer service has gone downhill in the last few years. Used to be able to call and talk to someone knowledgeable. Now it's all automated systems and long hold times.
author: CustomerServiceDecline

content: The resale value on Peterbilts is incredible. Sold my 2018 389 for only $20k less than I paid for it new. Try that with any other brand.
author: ResaleWinner

content: Anyone else having issues with the DEF quality sensor on the 579? Mine keeps throwing false codes. Dealer replaced it twice and it's still happening.
author: DEFSensorIssue

content: Just ordered a 2025 389 with all the options. 6 month wait time but it'll be worth it. Going with the Cummins X15 and 18-speed. Can't wait!
author: NewTruckExcitement

content: The 579 handles mountain grades better than any truck I've driven. Engine brake is strong and the transmission knows exactly when to downshift. Great for Rocky Mountain runs.
author: MountainDriver

content: Peterbilt needs to update their infotainment system. It looks like something from 2010. Even budget cars have better screens and interfaces now.
author: TechComplaint

content: Been driving Peterbilts for 30 years. The quality has definitely declined since the PACCAR acquisition. Old 379s were built to last forever. New trucks feel cheaper.
author: OldTimerOpinion

content: The 389 Pride and Class interior is worth the upgrade. Leather seats, wood trim, and better insulation. Makes those long hauls much more bearable.
author: LuxuryUpgrade

content: Warranty claim denied for turbo failure at 180k miles. Dealer says it's wear and tear. Turbo should last longer than that. Very disappointed with Peterbilt right now.
author: WarrantyDenied

content: The 579EV is interesting but not practical for my operation. 150 mile range doesn't cut it for regional haul. Maybe in 10 years when battery tech improves.
author: EVSkeptical

content: Peterbilt dealer network is solid in the Midwest but sparse out West. Had to drive 200 miles for warranty work when I broke down in Nevada. Not ideal.
author: DealerNetworkIssue
